channel.title: [Python][OO] Classes, Methods, StaticMethods. What are they?
channel.description:
Class - [i]A reference to an object[/i] [code] class Cake(object): [/code]
Method - [i]Just like a function, but something you do. First arguement is always [b]self[/b] for referring to the object.[/i]
[code] class Cake(object): def flavor(self): print "Chocolate!" [/code]
Static Method - [i]Methods callable without a class instance, do [b]not[/b] have a self arguement.[/i]
[code]
class Cake(object): def flavor(self): print "Chocolate!"
def take_slice(): print "You take a slice of cake!"
take_slice = staticmethod(take_slice) [/code]
:-)
If you want to define instance class atribiutes, you would add the __init__ method
like so
[code] class Cake(object): def __init__(self, slices, color):
self.slices = slices self.color = color
print "CAKE BAKED! YUM CAK"
def flavor(self): print "Chocolate!"
def take_slice(): print "You take a slice of cake!"
take_slice = staticmethod(take_slice)
Cake = Cake(slices = 10, color = "White") [/code]

item.description:
@thiefmn6092 wrote:

Class - A reference to an object

class Cake(object):

Method - Just like a function, but something you do. First arguement is always self for referring to the object.

class Cake(object):
     def flavor(self):
          print "Chocolate!"

Static Method - Methods callable without a class instance, do not have a self arguement.


class Cake(object):
    def flavor(self):
        print "Chocolate!"

    def take_slice():
        print "You take a slice of cake!"

    take_slice = staticmethod(take_slice)

If you want to define instance class atribiutes, you would add the init method

like so

[code]
class Cake(object):
def init(self, slices, color):

    self.slices = slices
    self.color = color

    print "CAKE BAKED! YUM CAK"

def flavor(self):
    print "Chocolate!"

def take_slice():
    print "You take a slice of cake!"

take_slice = staticmethod(take_slice)

Cake = Cake(slices = 10, color = “White”) [/code]
